The first line of the street address.
The second line of the street address.
The proper name of the city used to determine the Tax Area ID (if none is supplied). Optional (0..1) but recommended for greatest accuracy if no Tax Area ID is supplied.

The proper name or the postal abbreviation of the state, province, or territory used to determine the Tax Area ID if none is supplied. Optional (0..1) but is recommended for greatest accuracy if no Tax Area ID is supplied.
The name of the county used to determine the Tax Area ID if none is supplied. Optional (0..1) but is recommended for greatest accuracy if no Tax Area ID is supplied.

The postal code used to determine the Tax Area ID (if none is supplied). For valid formats, see the Supporting Information section in the XML Integration Guide. Optional (0..1) but recommended for greatest accuracy if no Tax Area ID is supplied.

The country used to determine the Tax Area ID (if none is supplied). You can use a Data Extract report to see the valid country values. (Refer to the Vertex Central online help for information on running Data Extract reports.) Defaults to the value of the taxgis.jurisdictionfinder.DefaultCountryCodeForAddress parameter. The default value for this parameter is USA. (For details on this configuration parameter, refer to the Configuration File Parameters Reference Guide.)

Core components used in the XML interface. Declararion of structures and data types.

A type of deduction that applies to sales that would normally be taxable but, because of special circumstances, are not. For example, the sale of machinery is normally subject to sales tax. However, when the machinery is used in manufacturing, some taxing jurisdictions consider the sale exempt. A certificate is usually required for an exemption to apply.
Copyright Vertex Inc. 2007-2009 All Rights Reserved

Indicates whether the Seller is not required to collect taxes. In this case, all associated child line items are exempt from taxes. You can use the Vertex Central user interface to create and maintain nexus requirements.

A code that indicates the reason that the Seller is exempt from tax. If your host system provides this functionality, this data element can be used. You can use the Vertex Central user interface to set up reason codes. Valid reason codes are expected from the host system and are pre-defined by Vertex for use in the Returns Export module in Vertex Central. Required (1) if the nexusIndicator is true. Note: To pass a standard (i.e., not user-defined) single-digit reason code, pad the code to four digits. Refer to the Supporting Information section of the XML Integration Guide for information on exemption and deduction reason codes.

Indicates that the buyer is not required to collect taxes, and all line items associated with the purchase order are exempt from taxes. It is recommended that the buyer and vendor nexus requirements be created and maintained in the Vertex Central user interface. Note: This attribute is set to true if you pass an exemption certificate number in the XML message.

A code that indicates the reason that the Buyer is exempt from tax. If your host system provides this functionality, this data element can be used. You can use the Vertex Central user interface to set up reason codes. Valid reason codes are expected from the host system and are pre-defined by Vertex for use in the Returns Export module in Vertex Central. Note: To pass a standard (i.e., not user-defined) single-digit reason code, pad the code to four digits. Refer to the Supporting Information section of the XML Integration Guide for information on exemption and deduction reason codes.
A standardized, unique code for the product or service.
The type of commodity code mapping.
A user-defined code that represents the customer for the transaction or line item.
A user-defined code that represents the dispatcher for the transaction or line item.
A user-defined code that represents the recipient for the transaction or line item.

A user-defined code that represents the vendor (external seller or vendor) for the transaction or line item. Use the Vertex Central user interface to set up any taxability rules that apply at this level. This should be a parameter that is configurable to data from the host system.
Details on the deduction override.

The amount used to override taxability to partial or full exempt status. If this data element is used to pass an override amount from the host system, the calculation engine ignores any applicable exceptions or overrides set up using the Vertex Central user interface. Vertex recommends that you use the Vertex Central user interface to create and maintain exceptions and overrides rather than using this data element.

A code that indicates the reason for the override. If your host system provides this functionality, this data element can be used. You can use the Vertex Central user interface to set up reason codes. Valid reason codes are expected from the host system and are pre-defined by Vertex for use in the Returns Export module in Vertex Central. Note: To pass a standard (i.e., not user-defined) single-digit reason code, pad the code to four digits. Refer to the Supporting Information section of the XML Integration Guide for information on exemption and deduction reason codes.

The amount used to override taxability to partial or full non-taxable status. If this data element is used to pass an override amount from the host system, the calculation engine ignores any applicable exceptions or overrides set up using the Vertex Central user interface. Vertex recommends that you use the Vertex Central user interface to create and maintain exceptions and overrides rather than using this data element.

A code that indicates the reason for the override. If your host system provides this functionality, this data element can be used. You can use the Vertex Central user interface to set up reason codes. Valid reason codes are expected from the host system and are pre-defined by Vertex for use in the Returns Export module in Vertex Central. Note: To pass a standard (i.e., not user-defined) single-digit reason code, pad the code to four digits. Refer to the Supporting Information section of the XML Integration Guide for information on exemption and deduction reason codes.
Details on the discount. To pass Discount information, pass either DiscountPercent or DiscountAmount, but not both.
The discount to be applied expressed as a percentage. Required (1) if no Discount Amount information is supplied.
The discount to be applied expressed as an amount. Required (1) if no Discount Percent information is supplied.
A user-defined code that maps to a Vertex-supplied discount category. You can use the Vertex Central user interface to map your discount codes to discount categories.
Details on the exemption certificate.

The identifier of the exemption certificate, which is recorded in the Tax Journal. Vertex recommends that you use the Vertex Central user interface to set up and maintain Exemption Certificates. Note: If you pass an exemption certificate number in the XML message, the isTaxExempt attribute of the participant is set to true and the transaction is treated as exempt from tax.

Indicator that alerts the host system of the need to add invoice text of a specific type to a line item. For a list of the codes and their meanings, see the Supporting Information section in the XML Integration Guide. Note: This transaction is considered to involve a VAT group if a value of 2 (Intra-EU Notice) is returned, the POS jurisdiction is an EU country, and the buyer and seller have the same registration number.
Details on the jurisdiction overrides.
The jurisdiction level of the overrides. Vertex recommends that you use the Vertex Central user interface to create and maintain jurisdiction overrides.

The type description assigned to the imposition. When multiple impositions are imposed within a jurisdiction, each must have a different type. This is assigned either by Vertex or by the user when setting up a user-defined imposition in the Vertex Central user interface.

A Vertex-defined term that is equivalent to the benefit received location in some service transactions. Required (1) for some service transactions at either the Transaction level or the Line Item level. If information is provided at both levels, the Line Item level information supersedes the Transaction level information.
A Vertex-defined term that is equivalent to the following terms: order taken, order acceptance, place of principle negotiation, or place of business.

This value is used when the buyer has paid a portion of the tax due on the invoice but an undercharge scenario occurs that required a partial accrual of tax or additional use tax may be due depending on the jurisdiction and usage of the Purchase. The amount paid from the invoice verification process should be passed so that partial accrual can be applied. Additional consumer use tax will be automatically accrued.

The actual basis cost to the purchaser for the materials of the asset. For manufacturers, this is the cost of the actual materials purchased for resale from outside suppliers. For wholesalers and retailers, this is the material cost of the property itself.

The rate (multiplier) used for converting the transaction currency amount to the filing currency amount. Pass in this value and the currency code (isoCurrencyCodeAlpha or isoCurrencyCodeNum) to have filing currency calculated if your configuration parameters are set up to do so.
ISO 4217 currency code structure
The ISO 4217 name for the currency unit. Not used for this version of O Series.
The three-character ISO 4217 alphabetic code for the currency unit.
The three-digit ISO 4217 numeric code for the currency unit.

A Vertex-defined term that is equivalent to the following terms: ship-to, benefit received, first used, where used, primary place of use, principle use location, location of property, or place of use. Required (1) at either the Transaction level or the Line Item level. If Destination information is provided at both levels, the Line Item level information supersedes the Transaction level information.
Dispatcher information. The dispatcher is described by the child elements and attributes.
This field specifies the actual price of the line item. However, if quantity and unit price are supplied, this is not required.
The basis price at which the asset could be sold to the public. This is also known as the selling price or the value of the product for sale.
Container for user-defined fields. Fields are provided for string values, numeric (double) values, and date values.
User-defined field for string values.
An identifier for a Flexible Code Field.
User-defined field for double values.
An identifier for a Flexible Numeric Field.
User-defined field for date values.
An identifier for a Flexible Date Field.

This field sets the freight charge associated with the line item. Note that the preferred method for dealing with freight is to create a separate line item with an item type mapped to one of the Vertex-provided Item Categories. However, using this method will calculate tax for the default Freight Item Category and roll it into this line item.
Information necessary for the calculation of recoverability of an input tax.
Identifies the jurisdiction where the tax is reported.
The tax rate as shown on the vendor invoice.
The rate to be used to override the standard rate to calculate Recoverable Input VAT.
Indicates that the input tax is Import VAT. Defaults to false.
Limits the taxes calculated for the transaction to a specific jurisdiction level and imposition type.

Categorizes the tax being imposed. It can be either Vertex-defined or user-defined. Examples of Vertex-defined imposition types include General Sales and Use Tax, Surcharge, and VAT. Note: If no value is provided for impositionType, all impositions for the specified Jurisdiction Level are processed.
The amount of Input Tax to be distributed. Negative numbers are permitted so that corrections may be processed
The amount of tax to be distributed.

Landed Costs are costs associated with transporting goods. They are additional costs beyond the merchandise cost of inventory incurred in purchasing and receiving items, for instance, freight, import duties, and customs charges. Landed Costs are added to the Extended Amount on a line item but are not subject to any discounts or adjustments
This represents the currency in which the original business transaction took place.
This value represents the amount of taxes paid previously on the asset. This information is needed to determine reciprocity rules between jurisdictions.

A Vertex-defined term that is equivalent to the following terms: ship-from or first removed. Required (1) for VAT triangulation at either Transaction level or the Line Item level. If Physical Origin information is provided at both levels, the Line Item level information supersedes the Transaction level information.

A code from the host system that identifies the product, material, service, or SKU number. You can use the Vertex Central user interface to map your products to Product Categories. If the supplied Product and Product Class information is not recognized by the calculation engine, a general category indicating TPP is assigned. Required (1) if no Product Class information is supplied. If both are supplied, Product information supersedes Product Class information.

A code used to represent groups or categories of products or services with similar taxability. You can use the Vertex Central user interface to map your products classes to Product Class Categories. If the supplied Product and Product Class information is not recognized by the calculation engine, a general category indicating TPP is assigned. Required (1) if no Product information is supplied. If both are supplied, Product information supersedes Product Class information.
A code from the host application that identifies the product, material, service or SKU code.
A code from the host application that identifies a general classification of product, material, service or SKU code.
Recipient information. The recipient is described by the child elements and attributes.

The rate override percentage for the specified jurisdiction. Vertex recommends that you use the Vertex Central user interface to create and maintain exceptions and overrides rather than using this data element.

The number of units included in the line item based on quantity and not a currency amount. This value is applied on a line item basis to the quantity level of the product. This application of tax differs from normal tax calculation because the tax amount/rate is applied at the quantity level of the item sold in the transaction and not to the purchase price. Required (1) if no Extended Price information is supplied.
Details on the situs determination overrides.
The address type to be used as the situs. Required if performing a situs override.
Sum of all extended amounts for line items in the transaction.
Details on the tax override.
Classifies the override as taxable or nontaxable.

A code that indicates the reason for the override. If your host system provides this functionality, this data element can be used. You can use the Vertex Central user interface to set up reason codes. Valid reason codes are expected from the host system and are pre-defined by Vertex for use in the Returns Export module in Vertex Central. Note: To pass a standard (i.e., not user-defined) single-digit reason code, pad the code to four digits. Refer to the Supporting Information section of the XML Integration Guide for information on exemption and deduction reason codes.

Registration information for Value Added Tax. Note: This transaction is considered to involve a group if the buyer and seller have the same registration number, the POS jurisdiction is an EU country, and a value of 2 (Intra-EU Notice) is returned for InvoiceTextCode.
Total tax amount of each line item.
Amount of tax based on variables of transaction.
The Unit Price is used in conjunction with the quantity to calculate an extended price, if one is not provided.
The volume of the product.
The weight of the product.
Indicates a status of Free Circulation.
Indicates that goods are in a Bonded or Customs Warehouse regime.
Indicates that goods are located in a Free-Trade or Enterprise Zone.
Indicates that goods have entered the location on a temporary basis and shall be exported within the allowable time frame.
Indicates that goods are subject to inward processing relief.
Indicates that goods are subject to outward processing relief.
The lookup returned at least one tax area.
The location information used during the lookup was incomplete or inconsistent.
The street address used during the lookup were incomplete or inconsistent.
Some of the location information was missing and may have been ignored during the lookup.

The maximum number of tax areas was exceeded. The maximum number of tax areas that can be returned during a lookup is specified in the taxgis.jurisdictionfinder.MaximumTaxAreas parameter. The default value for this parameter is 5. For details on the configuration parameters, refer to the Configuration File Parameters Reference Guide.

The maximum number of full addresses was exceeded. The maximum number of full addresses that can be returned during a lookup is specified in the taxgis.jurisdictionfinder.MaximumFullAddresses parameter. The default value for this parameter is 100. For details on the configuration parameters, refer to the Configuration File Parameters Reference Guide.

The minimum aggregate confidence has been exceeded. The minimum aggregate confidence indicator for returning tax areas is specified in the taxgis.jurisdictionfinder.MinimumAggregateConfidence parameter. The default value for this parameter is 100. For details on the configuration parameters, refer to the Configuration File Parameters Reference Guide.
The confidence indicator values were suppressed because the feature is not supported for the input criteria provided.
The confidence indicator feature has been disabled because the transaction date precedes the feature implementation date.
Indicates transfer of goods from one country to another to create a stock which is held in the second country under the owner's control. The stock is available for sale to multiple customers.

Indicates transfer of goods from one country to another to create a stock which is held in the second country for the use of a single customer. The stock is not intended for sale to any party other than the single customer.
Indicates that there is no special consignment stock or call off stock condition to be considered for tax calculation.
Identifies the transaction type

The 'Reason Code' can be passed through the ERP application if functionality is provided, however most Lessee's will set up reason codes associated with Lessee's in Vertex Central by the tax department. The valid reason codes are expected from the calling application and are pre-defined by Vertex for use in the Tax Returns application.
Identifies the transaction type
Indicates special handling of an Asset Movement transaction. Typically allows for the deferment of VAT, depending on the countries involved in the transaction.
Indicates special handling of an Asset Movement transaction. Typically allows for the deferment of VAT, depending on the countries involved in the transaction.
Indicates that the EU's 6th Directive triangulation simplification rules will be used to process the transaction.
Identifies the transaction as involving a VAT group even though the normal system logic would not identify a VAT group.
Identifies the type of synchronization to be performed.

Identifies a specific instance of tax area. A Tax Area is determined by the geographic areas that correspond to a unique combination of taxing jurisdictions where the tax area's boundaries are derived from the overlay of the geographic areas that form the domain of those jurisdictions.
Copyright Vertex Inc. 2007-2009 All Rights Reserved
System determination of taxable status based on situs and item type.
List of all parameters on the tax or line item that were assisted by one or more assisting services.
Element body is value for assisted parameter. Body may be date (yyyy-mm-dd), numeric (default format for long or double), boolean (true or false), or simple string.
Unique name by which the modified parameter can be identified.
Indicates whether the parameter was assisted pre-calculation or post-calculation.
The buyer for the transaction or line item. The buyer is described by the child elements and attributes.

A code used to represent groups of customers, vendors, dispatchers, or recipients who have similar taxability. Note: If you pass a classCode, you should not pass a TaxRegistrationNumber because the registration number does not apply to the entire class.
Indicates whether or not the participant is a business.

Indicates that the buyer is not required to collect taxes, and all line items associated with the purchase order are exempt from taxes. It is recommended that the buyer and vendor nexus requirements be created and maintained in the Vertex Central user interface. Note: this attribute is set to true if you pass an exemption certificate number in the XML message.

The 'Reason Code' can be passed through the ERP application if functionality is provided, however most Lessee's will set up reason codes associated with Lessee's in the Vertex Central user interface by the tax department. The valid reason codes are expected from the calling application and are pre-defined by Vertex for use in the Tax Returns application. Note: To pass a standard (i.e., not user-defined) single-digit reason code, pad the code to four digits. Refer to the Supporting Information section of the XML Integration Guide for information on exemption and deduction reason codes.
The name that this jurisdiction is commonly known. For example, Pennsylvania.
Copyright Vertex Inc. 2007-2008 All Rights Reserved
The level of the jurisdiction for which the tax on the line item is applied.
The Vertex-specific number that identifies a jurisdiction.
The date when the tax for the jurisdiction became effective.
The date after which the tax for the jurisdiction is no longer effective.
Jurisdiction code assigned by the relevant governmental authority.
A Vertex-specific number that identifies a tax area. If the Tax Area ID exists in your host system, use that data to populate this data element in a request message.
The customs status at this location.
A value that can be used for tax return filing in jurisdictions that require taxes to be filed for individual retail locations.
Jurisdiction code assigned by the relevant governmental authority.
System Login. Declaration of structure and data types.
Copyright Vertex Inc. 2007-2009 All Rights Reserved
The User ID of the individual initiating the login.
The password associated with the User ID of the individual initiating the login.
An identifier supplied by an ERP.

The unit of measure for the line item to be used in surcharges based on quantity and not price. For a list of the possible values, see the Supporting Information section of the XML Integration Guide. If you pass a value that does not match the unit of measure for the quantity-based tax rule, that rule is not used. May be Required (1) to determine tax liability in some jurisdictions.
Specialized participant to mark taxpayer in DOM.
An identifier to distinguish between user-defined rules from Vertex-defined rules.This can be used as a troubleshooting aid.
Indicates whether this rule applies as a Sales Tax Holiday.
The Vertex-defined Tax Area ID for the jurisdiction.
Jurisdiction code assigned by the relevant governmental authority.

The country associated with the external jurisdiction code. You can use a Data Extract report to see the valid country values. (Refer to the Vertex Central online help for information on running Data Extract reports.)
A date that provides time perspective for a Tax Area lookup. Tax Area IDs returned for the lookup are based on the jurisdiction boundaries in effect as of this date. Defaults to the current date.
Internal identifier or sequence number for this lookup.
Represents the result of the lookup process.
The lookup result status.
A Vertex-specific number that identifies a tax area.
A date that provides time perspective for a Tax Area lookup. Tax Area IDs returned for the lookup are based on the jurisdiction boundaries in effect as of this date. Defaults to the current date.
Indicates the relative likelihood that a result of a tax area lookup is correct based on the lookup criteria.
Taxes calculated by the transaction processing system.
The name of jurisdiction to which a tax is applied.
Amount of tax calculated by the calculation engine.

For Buyer Input tax and Seller Import tax, this rate is calculated based on the Extended Price and Tax Amount (Import or Input) passed in the Request message. If you total the Extended Price and Tax Amounts before passing them in, this rate is an average. For all other message types, this is the effective rate the system used to calculate tax.
Amount of the line item not subject to tax due to exempt status.
Amount of the line item not subject to tax due to nontaxable status.
Amount of the line item subject to tax.
The name of the imposition to which the relevant tax rule belongs. This is assigned either by Vertex or by the user when setting up a user-defined imposition in the Vertex Central user interface.

The type description assigned to the imposition. When multiple impositions are imposed within a jurisdiction, each must have a different type. This is assigned either by Vertex or by the user when setting up a user-defined imposition in the Vertex Central user interface.
An identifier for the tax rule that was used in tax calculation. This can be used as a troubleshooting aid.
An identifier for the basis rule that was used in tax calculation. This can be used as a troubleshooting aid.
An identifier for the Max Tax rule that was used in tax calculation. This can be used as a troubleshooting aid.
The certificate number associated with the line item tax.
The certificate type associated with the line item tax.
The amount of input or import tax that the buyer is able to recover on a transaction. This is the amount that the Buyer puts on their returns in order to recover these funds.
The percent of the tax that is recoverable, as calculated based on passed in recoverable amount and tax. Expressed as a decimal: 1.0 for 100%, .8 for 80%, .5 for 50%, and so on.
The amount of input or import tax that the taxpayer is not able to recover. It is lost, which is a true cost to the taxpayer.
A grouping of filing currency converted taxability amounts.
The Registration ID for the Seller associated with this line item tax.
The Registration ID for the Buyer associated with this line item tax.
The Registration ID for the Owner associated with this line item tax.
The Registration ID for the Dispatcher associated with this line item tax.
The Registration ID for the Recipient associated with this line item tax.

Additional information about a tax, to be returned to your host system after tax calculation. To supply a value for this field, you need to set up a post-calculation Tax Assist rule. Note: The text you add to this field is not stored in the Tax Journal.
System determination of taxable status based on situs and item type. Note: Tax amounts with a value of Deferred are payable at a later time and should NOT be written to the invoice.
System determined tax type, based on situs, transaction type, and party role type (perspective).
Indicates that max tax was applied to this line item of the invoice.
The situs determined by the calculation engine for the line item.
Indicates that the taxpayer company is not registered in the taxing jurisdiction.
Identifies whether tax is Input VAT, Output VAT, or both according to the perspective of the transaction to allow for Reverse Charges.
A user-defined code for the tax, to be returned to your host system after tax calculation. To return a value for this field, set up a post-calculation Tax Assist rule.

A code that can be used to classify the transaction at the tax level for reporting or tax return filing purposes. The code is generated by the Calculation Engine for each line item after tax calculation. It can be used as a filter for reports or as an input for post-calculation Tax Assist rules. For detailed information about the contents of the code, see the Supporting Information section of the XML Integration Guide.

A code that indicates the reason for the exception that was applied to this tax. Note: For a tax with multiple tiers, O Series returns the reason code associated with the largest basis amount. Note: To pass a standard (i.e., not user-defined) single-digit reason code, pad the code to four digits. Refer to the Supporting Information section of the XML Integration Guide for information on exemption and deduction reason codes.

Provides additional classification of the transaction for tax returns and reporting. Codes are jurisdiction-specific. Note: For a tax with multiple tiers, O Series returns the filing category code associated with the largest basis amount.
Indicates whether or not the product is a service.

A Vertex-defined classification of the applicable tax rule for returns filing purposes. Possible values are: Luxury Rate, Standard Rate, Reduced Rate 1, Reduced Rate 2, Reduced Rate 3, Reduced Rate 4, Reduced Rate 5, User Defined, Zero Rate, Outside the Scope.
The party who is responsible for the sales tax. Note: Tax amounts with a value of Seller cannot be charged to your customer and should NOT be written to the invoice.
Parent type for all Taxgis request messages
Parent type for all Taxgis response messages
Identifies the jurisdiction level to which the tax applies.
Categorizes the tax being imposed. It can be either Vertex-defined or user-defined.

Identifies the top-level legal entity for which tax exceptions may exist. The Vertex Central user interface is used to set up any taxability rules that apply at this level. This should be a parameter that is configurable to data from the host system based on an individual company's legal and tax requirements.

Identifies the mid-level legal entity for which tax exceptions may exist. The Vertex Central user interface is used to set up any taxability rules that apply at this level. This should be a parameter that is configurable to data from the host system based on an individual company's legal and tax requirements.

Identifies the low-level legal entity for which specific tax requirements and exceptions may exist. Use the Vertex Central user interface to set up any taxability rules that apply at this level. Based on your legal/tax liabilities at this level, map the appropriate host system parameter to this data element. If all of your tax exceptions are at the top- or mid-level entity, you may choose not to populate this data element. Note that this data element is also used to sort reports.
The tax registration ID number.
Information for the nexus override.
The location for the nexus override.
Indicates whether or not the override applies at this jurisdiction level.
Indicates whether or not the override applies at this jurisdiction level.
Indicates whether or not the override applies at this jurisdiction level.
Indicates whether or not the override applies at this jurisdiction level.
Indicates whether or not the override applies at this jurisdiction level.
The physical location associated with the tax registration. Use the taxAreaId or address information to identify the physical location.
The Vertex-defined Tax Area ID for the location.
The 2-character or 3-character alphabetic ISO 3166 code indicating the country represented by the registration.
The proper name or postal abbreviation of the state, province, or territory of the tax registration.
Indicates whether or not the entity has a physical presence in the country represented by the registration.
Parent type for all Tax Synchronization request messages
Parent type for all Tax Synchronziation response message
Parent type for all Tax Transaction request messages
Parent type for all Tax Transaction response messges

Accrual transaction composite messages. Declaration of structure and data types.
Line Item declaration for Accrual Request message.
The buyer for the line item. The buyer is described by the child elements and attributes.
The vendor for the line item. The vendor is described by the child elements and attributes.

This value is used when the buyer has paid a portion of the tax due on the line item but an undercharge scenario occurs that required a partial accrual of tax or additional use tax may be due depending on the jurisdiction and usage of the Purchase. The amount paid from the invoice verification process should be passed so that partial accrual can be applied. Additional consumer use tax will be automatically accrued.
A sub-component (or child line item) of the transaction.
Line Item declaration for Accrual Response message.
The buyer for the line item.
The vendor for the line item.
A sub-component (or child line item) of the transaction.

The request used in self-accrual situations. These situations occur when the purchaser must remit tax on tangible personal property or services (used or consumed) when tax is due but has not been paid. Use Tax Accrual transactions are written to the Tax Journal. Some examples of self-accrual situations include when a seller does not have nexus in the purchaser's state and does not collect tax, when non-exempt tangible personal property is purchased without tax and is subsequently used in a taxable manner (and the purchaser has provided the seller a direct pay permit), when a company uses items from inventory in a taxable manner (and the purchaser has provided the seller a resale certificate).
The buyer for the transaction. The buyer is described by the child elements and attributes.
The vendor for the transaction. The vendor is described by the child elements and attributes.

Line Item declaration for Asset Movement Request message.

The owner of the goods in the line item. Required (1) at either the Transaction level or the Line Item level. If Owner information is provided at both levels, the Line Item level information supersedes the Transaction level information.
This value represents the amount of taxes paid previously on the asset. This information is needed to determine reciprocity rules between jurisdictions.

This is the actual cost of the materials to the purchaser. In a manufacturing environment, this would be the cost of the actual materials purchased for resale from outside suppliers. Wholesalers and retailers would measure material cost by the cost of the property itself.
Cost less depreciation. The depreciation method will be dependent on the state rules (straightline depreciation, declining depreciation, etc.).

The value of the raw materials plus all other costs such as direct labor, transportation, and indirect materials consumed and charged to the product overhead, etc. (a.k.a. Standard Cost, Manufactured Cost, Total Manufacturer's Cost).
This is the rental value of the property on the open market.
A sub-component (or child line item) of the transaction.

This is the rental value of the property on the open market.
A sub-component (or child line item) of the transaction.

The request used to calculate consumer use tax on movement of fixed assets from one tax jurisdiction to another. Whenever an asset is moved, the use tax rates and rules for the new location must be compared with the use tax rates and rules for the old location. Various reciprocity rules, which vary by tax jurisdiction, may need to be applied in these situations. Two factors that can be used to determine reciprocity are duration at a location and the number of times that an asset was moved. Asset Movement transactions are written to the Tax Journal when additional use tax must be accrued at the new location.

The owner of the goods in the transaction. Required (1) at either the Transaction level or the Line Item level. If Owner information is provided at both levels, the Line Item level information supersedes the Transaction level information.

The request used to accept a combined total tax amount for a purchase and distribute that tax to the appropriate jurisdictions. The combined rates for the taxing jurisdictions are used with the total tax amount to determine the taxable base and then redistribute the calculated taxes to each level for remittance. Vertex Central rules in effect as of the date in the documentDate attribute are used. If records for jurisdiction registration, product exception, or customer exception or exemption are dated on or before that date, they are used in the calculation process. Distribute Consumer Use Tax transactions are written to the Tax Journal.

The request used to calculate tax when a formalized agreement exists between the buyer and seller that places the tax calculation burden on the buyer. In these situations, no invoice is actually issued by the seller; rather, the buyer relies on pre-established terms (represented in a purchase order or other agreement) to calculate their obligation and remit payment directly to the seller. A current knowledge of the seller's tax status (for example, where they have nexus) must be maintained to assess tax at the proper rate. ERS transactions are written to the Tax Journal.

Indicates that that the buyer is not required to collect taxes, and all line items associated with the purchase order are exempt from taxes. It is recommended that the buyer and vendor nexus requirements be created and maintained in the Vertex Central user interface. Note: This attribute is set to true if you pass an exemption certificate number in the XML message.

A code that indicates the reason that the Buyer is exempt from tax. If your host system provides this functionality, this data element can be used. You can use the Vertex Central user interface to set up reason codes. Valid reason codes are expected from the host system and are pre-defined by Vertex for use in the Returns Export module in Vertex Central. Note: To pass a standard (i.e., not user-defined) single-digit reason code, pad the code to four digits. Refer to the Supporting Information section of the XML Integration Guide for information on exemption and deduction reason codes.

This is the actual cost of the materials to the purchaser. In a manufacturing environment, this would be the cost of the actual materials purchased for resale from outside suppliers. Wholesalers and retailers would measure material cost by the cost of the property itself.
Cost less depreciation. The depreciation method will be dependent on the state rules (straightline depreciation, declining depreciation, etc.).

The value of the raw materials plus all other costs such as direct labor, transportation, and indirect materials consumed and charged to the product overhead, etc. (a.k.a. Standard Cost, Manufactured Cost, Total Manufacturer's Cost).
This is the price at which the property is sold to the public. (A.K.A Selling Price, Value of the product for Sale)
This is the rental value of the property on the open market.

A sub-component (or child line item) of the transaction.

Use the Invoice Verification schemas to verify sales or seller use tax on incoming invoices to the buyer for tangible personal property, rentals, leases, and services. The invoice is recreated from the seller's perspective to validate that the proper tax has been applied. The interface verifies the total tax amount on the original invoice versus the calculated amount. User-defined thresholds for tolerance are validated at the transaction level or line item level and an indicator is returned for undercharges and overcharges outside these settings. No tax may be on the invoice if the buyer has filed a direct pay permit with the vendor. All Invoice Verification transactions are written to the Tax Journal. If the Invoice Verification transaction falls within the user-defined threshold, the calculation engine automatically determines if any consumer use tax is due in any jurisdictions. If any consumer use tax is due, the amount is returned with the ConsumerUseTaxDue element in the response message. The result of this consumer use tax calculation is not written to the Tax Journal. If you require this detail to be recorded in the Tax Journal, pass a separate Use Tax Accrual transaction.
The buyer for the transaction. The buyer is described by the child elements and attributes.
The vendor for the transaction. The vendor is described by the child elements and attributes.

The request used to accept a combined total tax amount for a purchase and distribute that tax to the appropriate jurisdictions. The combined rates for the taxing jurisdictions are used with the total tax amount to determine the taxable base and then redistribute the calculated taxes to each level for remittance. This request is also used for a tax-only adjustment (debit or credit) so you can reconcile a tax underpayment or overpayment. Vertex Central rules in effect as of the date in the documentDate attribute are used. If records for jurisdiction registration, product exception, or customer exception or exemption are dated on or before that date, they are used in the calculation process. A Distribute Tax Procurement transaction does impact revenue except when you designate it as a tax-only adjustment. Distribute Tax Procurement transactions are written to the Tax Journal.
Distribute Tax Procurement Response message.

The request used to accept a combined total tax amount for a purchase and distribute that tax to the appropriate jurisdictions. Vertex Central rules in effect as of the date in the documentDate attribute are used. If records for jurisdiction registration, product exception, or customer exception or exemption are dated on or before that date, they are used in the calculation process.
